Spherical to cartesian multipole transformation

23 February, 2022

Source: vignettes/110_alpha_tensor/110_alpha_tensor.Rmd
110_alpha_tensor.Rmd

This example illustrates the conversion from spherical to cartesian multipoles for the collective T-matrix of a cluster, following Mun et al.Â (Describing Meta-Atoms Using the Exact Higher-Order Polarizability Tensors, ACS Photonics 2020, 7, 1153âˆ’1162).

The geometry consists of a chiral dimer of prolate spheroids, modelled as electric dipoles (higher-order terms are ignored).

This simulation uses the following input file

ModeAndScheme 2 3

MultipoleCutoff 4
Medium 1.0

OutputFormat HDF5 EE1

DumpCollectiveTmatrix collective_tmat_EE1.tmat

MultipoleSelections 1
EE1:1_MM2:1_ME2:1_EM2:1  blocks

Wavelength 520

Medium 1.7689

TmatrixFiles 1
"tmat_Au20x50_Nmax4_lambda520.tmat" 

# dimer, dihedral pi/4
Scatterers 2
TF1_S1 0 -50 0 50 0 1.963495  0.0  2.5
TF1_S1 0 50  0 50 0 1.178097  0.0  2.5

where the keyword DumpCollectiveTmatrix triggers the output of the collective T-matrix, and also a plain text file alpha_col.txt containing the cartesian components up to Lmax=3.

Show output file alpha_col.txt (click to open)
